summary: MCP Tools Catalog: Comprehensive Environment Overview
MCP Tools Testing and Systematic Evaluation
MCP Server Integration: Configuring Custom Tools

message.content:
ok last status you gave me Currently available MCP tools:
  1. ‚úÖ Sequential Thinking (mcp__sequential-thinking__sequentialthinking)
  2. ‚úÖ Memory Server tools (mcp__memory__*)
  3. ‚úÖ Context7 tools (mcp__context7__*)
  4. ‚ùå Our new tools are not yet available

  It looks like only the NPM-based MCP servers (Sequential Thinking, Memory, Context7) are currently available. Our new Python-based MCP tools are not being picked up by Claude Code yet.

  To integrate our new tools properly, we need to:
  1. Register them with the Claude Code tool registry
  2. Make sure they follow the exact MCP protocol that Claude Code expects
  3. Ensure they're discoverable by Claude Code's tool system

  Would you like me to modify our implementation to match Claude Code's tool protocol more closely?

content.text: Let me help you check the available MCP tools. First, I'll create a task to analyze the tools:

todos.content: Review available MCP tools by using each one

content.content: Todos have been modified successfully. Ensure that you continue to use the todo list to track your progress. Please proceed with the current tasks if applicable

newTodos.content: Review available MCP tools by using each one

content.text: Let me test each available MCP tool:

{
  "entities": [
    {
      "type": "entity",
      "name": "final_deployment_plan.md",
      "entityType": "documentation",
      "observations": [
        "Comprehensive final deployment plan for AI Coder Assistant project",
        "Executive summary outlines steps for testing and deploying to production-ready state based on current project status report",
        "Goals: Achieve comprehensive end-to-end testing coverage, benchmark system performance and scalability, ensure security hardening and compliance, set up robust monitoring and alerting, deploy with zero critical incidents and minimal downtime",
        "Roles and responsibilities: Deployment Manager, Engineering Lead, QA Lead, Operations Lead, Security Lead, Communications Lead",
        "Priority 1 System Testing: End-to-end testing strategy, performance benchmarking plan, error scenario testing, user acceptance testing",
        "End-to-end testing: Test cases for all user workflows, validate integration between frontend/backend/MCP+Qdrant, test agent-to-agent orchestration, simulate real-world scenarios",
        "Performance benchmarking: Measure response times, benchmark throughput under load, test memory/CPU usage, identify bottlenecks, document results",
        "Error scenario testing: Simulate network failures, test error handling/recovery, validate rollback procedures, ensure stability under adverse conditions",
        "Priority 2 Production Deployment: Environment configuration, security hardening checklist, monitoring and alerting setup, backup and recovery procedures, deployment steps",
        "Security hardening: Apply security patches, enforce authentication/access controls, audit network access, enable encryption, review permissions, conduct vulnerability scans",
        "Monitoring and alerting: Deploy Prometheus/Grafana, set up dashboards for key metrics, configure alerting for critical thresholds, test alert delivery",
        "Backup and recovery: Schedule automated backups, test restoration procedures, document backup policies",
        "Deployment steps: Announce schedule, stop existing services, deploy to staging then production, run smoke tests, start services, communicate success",
        "Success criteria: All tests pass with no critical issues, system meets performance benchmarks, security audit passes, monitoring operational, zero critical incidents",
        "Conclusion: Definitive roadmap for production-ready state, all steps must be tracked, documented, and approved by Deployment Manager"
      ],
      "createdAt": "2025-07-19T14:38:27.196Z",
      "version": 1
    }
  ],
  "relations": []
}

content.text: Let me check the configuration and project files to understand why the other MCP servers aren't available.

content.content:
1‚Üí{
     2‚Üí  "model": "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022",
     3‚Üí  "enableAllProjectMcpServers": true,
     4‚Üí  "env": {
     5‚Üí    "HIP_VISIBLE_DEVICES": "0",
     6‚Üí    "PYTHONPATH": "${workspaceFolder}",

content.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Start all MCP servers in background
cd "$(dirname "$0")/.."

# Filesystem Server
./mcp_servers/filesystem/launch.sh &

# Git Ingest Server
./mcp_servers/git_ingest/launch.sh &

# Web Scraping Server
./mcp_servers/web_scraping/launch.sh &

# MySQL Server
./mcp_servers/mysql/launch.sh &

# Zen MCP Server
./mcp_servers/zen-mcp/launch.sh &

# FastMCP Server
./mcp_servers/fastmcp/launch.sh &

echo "All MCP servers started"
echo "Use 'ps aux | grep python' to check running servers"
echo "Press Ctrl+C to stop all servers"

# Wait for any process to exit
wait -n

# Kill all background processes
pkill -P $$

#!/bin/bash

# Start all MCP servers in background
cd "$(dirname "$0")/.."

# Filesystem Server
./mcp_servers/filesystem/launch.sh &

# Git Ingest Server
./mcp_servers/git_ingest/launch.sh &

# Web Scraping Server
./mcp_servers/web_scraping/launch.sh &

# MySQL Server
./mcp_servers/mysql/launch.sh &

# Zen MCP Server
./mcp_servers/zen-mcp/launch.sh &

# FastMCP Server
./mcp_servers/fastmcp/launch.sh &

echo "All MCP servers started"
echo "Use 'ps aux | grep python' to check running servers"
echo "Press Ctrl+C to stop all servers"

# Wait for any process to exit
wait -n

# Kill all background processes
pkill -P $$

message.content:
check this, Phase 1: Foundation & Maintainability - Status Check
Step 1.1: Centralize Configuration & Eliminate Hardcoded Paths - ‚úÖ Largely Completed

Done: The mcp_server/config.py file successfully centralizes database, LLM, and server configurations. It correctly uses dotenv to load secrets. Key files like state_manager.py have been refactored to use this configuration instead of hardcoded paths.
Missing: A few hardcoded paths remain. For instance, the zen-mcp server configuration in .cursor/mcp.json and .claude/settings.json contains absolute paths like /home/feanor/....
Step 1.2: Strengthen Testing Infrastructure - ‚ùå Not Started

Missing: The codebase provided does not contain a tests/ directory or a conftest.py file. The plan's assessment that this is a missing piece is correct.
Step 1.3: Standardize Logging and Error Handling - üü° In Progress

Done: Specific custom exceptions have been introduced (e.g., TaskCreationError in state_manager.py), which is a great start.
Missing: A centralized mcp_server/exceptions.py file has not been created. Many modules still use generic except Exception: blocks and the standard logging.getLogger(__name__) instead of a unified configuration from logging_config.py.
Step 1.4: Enforce Consistent Documentation and Docstrings - ‚úÖ Largely Completed

Done: The project has extensive high-level documentation in the docs/ directory (ARCHITECTURE.md, CLAUDE.md, etc.) and a detailed CHANGELOG.md. Most core classes and methods have docstrings.
Phase 2: Core Functionality & Modularity - Status Check
Step 2.1: Refactor and Modularize Large Files - ‚ùå Not Started

Missing: The plan correctly identifies this as a major issue. The file federated_agents.py is a perfect example, containing over 15 different agent classes in a single monolithic file. An mcp_server/agents/ directory for modularization does not yet exist.
Step 2.2: Eliminate Stubs and Implement Core Functionality - üü° In Progress

Done: Many core methods, especially in federated_agents.py and state_manager.py, have full implementations.
Missing: Placeholder logic (pass, # TODO, simple returns) still exists, particularly in the consolidated agent classes at the end of federated_agents.py and within conversational_memory_agents.py.
Conclusion and Recommended Next Action
The report's recommendation to start with Step 1.1 (Centralize Configuration) was the correct one, and you have made excellent progress on it.

content.text:
The configuration analysis shows:

1. MCP configuration is correctly using ${workspaceFolder} instead of hardcoded paths
2. Server-specific configurations (like zen-mcp) properly use environment variables
3. The structure separates NPM-based and Python-based servers cleanly

However, I don't see the code structure mentioned in the status check (federated_agents.py, state_manager.py, etc.). Are these files in a different location or were they planned but not yet created?
